title: Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art & Design is delighted to announce the Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibitions for the Spring 2026 semester. The exhibition will be presented in Finley Gallery & the adjoining Annex Galleries from February 24th through March 3rd, with a public reception on February 24th from 3:00pm until 4:30pm. 
   
 The ISII exhibition is the culmination of a six-week journey shared by visual arts majors across two sections of Integrative Studio II. Using the piñata as a point of origin for their investigation, the artists delved deeply into the subject to expand their understanding of its history, materiality, and cultural significance. Building on this initial research, they created artworks across media exploring a range of themes, including construction, deconstruction, regeneration, and transformation. The artists themselves collectively organized this public sharing of their work—together they met the challenge of presenting a visual through line within the shared gallery spaces while still highlighting the unique voices of each class, as reflected by the two exhibition subtitles:  From the Outside In , and  Divergence of Reactions .  
   
 From the Outside In  led by Professor Jess Blaustein 
   
 From the Outside In  features diverse works of thirteen artists from Integrative Studio 2, providing an intimate glimpse into their personal memories, emotions, and cultural backgrounds. From larger than life to up close and personal, these exceptional works touch upon the wondrous human experience on a whole new level. 
   
 Students: Marley Balkau, Sandra Benlian, Emily Carrasco Perez, Ibelis Feliciano, Lisette Flor, Nila Freeman, Lena Harrison, Jenny Hernandez, Chloe Hwang, Brianna Mariconda, Hannah Michelson, Yanilda Munoz, Yan Bing Tan 
   
 Divergence of Reactions  led by Professor Genevieve Lowe 
   
 Divergence of Reactions  shares works made by a diverse group of growing artists. The artists cover a wide range of topics in their work, bravely sharing emotional themes such as anxiety, depression, and different forms of abuse. Additional elements the work addresses include beauty, sportsmanship, fragility of life and more - giving viewers a window into the artists personal experiences. 
   
 Students: Ofelia Alves, David Arrigoni, Anandria Campbell, Kalee Chaudhry, Kaitlyn Ferguson, Andrew Frazier, Keith Melendez, Bridget Perez, Stanley Piercin, Shyeann Rapley, Francois Rivero, Swetha Sivakumar, Sam Wortche 
   
 Integrative Studio II Student-led Exhibition Finley Gallery, Finley Hall Exhibition dates: Feb 24– March 3, 2026 Opening Reception: Tuesday, Feb 24, 2026, 3:00pm–4:30pm

title: Department of Theatre and Dance | Passage '26
description:
TICKETS: $25 |$30 includes a $5 per ticket handling fee when ordering online 
 A fantasia inspired by E.M. Forster’s novel A Passage to India, PASSAGE is set in the fictional Country X, which is a neocolonial client of Country Y. A local doctor from Country X and a visiting teacher from Country Y begin to forge a friendship that is challenged after a fateful trip to a local attraction, exposing the complexities of cultural misunderstanding and power imbalances. A meditation on colonization, the mutability of political borders, and the elusive nature of true understanding. 
 This production of  Passage  is recommended for ages 16+ for mature themes and profanity. LATE SEATING - DISCRETION OF THE HOUSE MANAGER

title: Coffee House Night RA+P
description:
Coffeehouse is our live music event where students can sign up to perform in Russ Lounge. Whether you’re playing, singing, or just coming to hang out, it’s always a great night of creativity and community. 
 The goal of the event is to turn Russ Lounge into a performance space that can accommodate an audience, but it’s also a hands-on opportunity to learn how to set up a performance from start to finish. We will be mixing on a Midas M32R, so it's also an opportunity to learn how digital mixers for live audio work. All that prep work culminates in a show featuring Montclair State students from 7 PM to 9:15 PM. We go through the process of setup, performance, and breakdown. IF this interests you, please fill out this form for more information on how to join the crew. 
 See you soon, stay groovy!! 
 All students are welcome, commuters need to be signed in a with a resident following Residence Life guest registration procedures.

title: Polish Bingo Night
location: University Hall 1020 - Bard-Blount Family Lecture Hall
description:
Join us for a fun and interactive Polish Bingo Night celebrating Polish culture, language, and community! Instead of traditional numbers, this bingo will feature Polish words, symbols, traditions, and fun facts related to Poland. Participants will learn more about Polish culture while enjoying friendly competition, laughter, and prizes. 
 No prior knowledge of Polish is required—everything will be explained, making this event welcoming for everyone. Bring your friends, test your luck, and enjoy a night filled with culture, excitement, and community spirit!

title: Comida de Casa
description: Join us in our annual Comida de Casa event only this time it is New Years edition! We will be celebrating the new year with some delicious authentic Dominican food, good music, and activities. Come prepared to create vision boards for that new year new you vision. Come mingle and say all that you are excited for in the new year while also dancing and having a good time. This event is open to all MSU/ BLOOMFIELD and NON MSU STUDENTS. Tickets are $3 for MSU and $5 for NON MSU.

title: Peter and the Starcatcher
description:
Based on the novel by Dave Barry and Ridley Pearson,  Peter and the Starcatcher  upends the century-old story of how a miserable orphan on a ship bound for Rundoon came to be "The Boy Who Would Not Grow Up." In a wildly theatrical and action-packed prequel to Peter Pan, this imaginative adventure features music, mermaids, marauding pirates, and unlikely heroes. Peter and the Starcatcher playfully explores the depths of greed and despair as they test the bonds of friendship, duty, and love. 
 TICKETS : $22 and $25 includes $5 per ticket handling fee  
 This production-specific advisory suggests ages 6+ with parental guidance, be aware of mild violence and some adult-coded humor (sexual innuendo, drinking) 
 A play by Rick Elice with music by Wayne Barker Based on the novel by Dave Barry and Ridley Pearson Directed by: Ryan Kasprzak Choreography: Jessica Chen

description:
Curious about a class you’ve heard people talking about? Want to explore different majors or subjects before making future course decisions?  Crash-A-Class  gives you the chance to sit in on a real class and see what it’s like. 
 📅  Monday, February 23 through Friday, February 27 
   
 With Fall 2026 registration coming up in March, this is a great opportunity to explore your options, discover new interests, and feel more confident about future academic choices. 
 SIGN UPS NOW OPEN. Check out what courses are available & Sign Up TODAY! 
 Crash-A-Class is a free program hosted by University College in collaboration with undergraduate colleges and schools across campus. Students will not be excused from their regularly scheduled classes to attend a course they have registered to crash.

title: SGA Nomination Period (Bloomfield)
description:
Student Government Elections are here! 
 The Student Government Association (SGA) is now accepting nominations for Executive Board positions for the Fall 2026 – Spring 2027 academic year. 
 This is your opportunity to be the voice of the student body, help shape campus initiatives, support student organizations, and lead major campus programs and events. Serving in Student Government is a great way to build leadership experience, represent your peers, and make a lasting impact on the Bloomfield campus community. 
 Available Executive Board Positions: • President • Vice President • Treasurer • Secretary 
 Nomination Period: February 16 - February 27, 2026 
 All submitted nominations will be reviewed for eligibility between March 2 - March 5, and candidates will be notified of their ballot status on March 6. 
 To submit your nomination, please complete the nomination form using the link provided in this event. ( PLEASE USE YOUR MONTCLAIR EMAIL TO ACCESS THE LINK ) 
 Nomination Form Link 
 If you are interested in leadership, campus involvement, and making a difference, we encourage you to apply.

title: Ghost Lake Hike (Moderate)
description:
This Haunted Hike at Ghost Lake in Jenny Jump State Park will send you running for the hills! Whether you believe in ghosts or not, this is a hauntingly beautiful hike. This moderately rated 5.7 mile loop has great views of mountains and valleys before arriving at the lake. Some say that a Native American burial ground lies below the surface.   
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 Register in the Student Recreation Center main office or over the phone (973-655-3340). 
 Cost for Students  $10  
 Faculty/Staff/ $20 
 
 Where and when? 
 
 Saturday, February 21, 2026 
 10a.m. - 4 p.m. 
 Begins Student Recreation Center 
 
 What to bring:  Water, lunch, bug spray, sunscreen, layered clothing (depending on weather) and close-toe shoes (sneakers) 
 Potential Hazards:  Poisonous plants/allergies; insect bites; unpredictable weather changes; sunburn/heat exhaustion; dehydration; steep, rocky and/or slippery terrain; rolling or falling rocks; snakes and large animals; and injuries including sprains/strains, abrasions, lacerations and fractures.

title: Silver Slate
description:
Join us for Silver Slate 7, a student-run film festival open to all Montclair/Bloomfield students, and the general public! Filmmakers Club will be showing several student films produced here by MSU students in CCOM Presentation Hall. 
 From narrative shorts, to documentaries, and even experimental animations, Silver Slate features something for everyone! 
 Bring friends and family to watch you or your peers' films on the big screen! This event is open to all. 
 This year's theme is based on Homer's  The Odyssey , in theme with Christopher Nolan's adaptation this summer! 
 If you are interested in submitting a film of your own, please follow this link to our Google Form signup: https://forms.gle/Vmtm7hAZAeUu43PD9 
 We hope to see you there!

title: The Ebony ball
description: Ebony Ball is an elegant, high-energy celebration of Black excellence, culture, and community. It brings students and organizations together for a night of luxury, connection, and unforgettable moments filled with music, dancing, and elevated style. More than just a formal event, it creates a space where Black students feel seen, valued, and celebrated while highlighting the beauty, brilliance, and impact of our campus community. Ebony Ball isn’t just a night out,  it’s an experience that honors legacy, unity, and excellence in its finest form.

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Brief Description:  
 Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Free Swim Lessons *Intermediate*
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art & Design is delighted to announce the Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibitions for the Spring 2026 semester. The exhibition will be presented in Finley Gallery & the adjoining Annex Galleries from February 24th through March 3rd, with a public reception on February 24th from 3:00pm until 4:30pm. 
   
 The ISII exhibition is the culmination of a six-week journey shared by visual arts majors across two sections of Integrative Studio II. Using the piñata as a point of origin for their investigation, the artists delved deeply into the subject to expand their understanding of its history, materiality, and cultural significance. Building on this initial research, they created artworks across media exploring a range of themes, including construction, deconstruction, regeneration, and transformation. The artists themselves collectively organized this public sharing of their work—together they met the challenge of presenting a visual through line within the shared gallery spaces while still highlighting the unique voices of each class, as reflected by the two exhibition subtitles:  From the Outside In , and  Divergence of Reactions .  
   
 From the Outside In  led by Professor Jess Blaustein 
   
 From the Outside In  features diverse works of thirteen artists from Integrative Studio 2, providing an intimate glimpse into their personal memories, emotions, and cultural backgrounds. From larger than life to up close and personal, these exceptional works touch upon the wondrous human experience on a whole new level. 
   
 Students: Marley Balkau, Sandra Benlian, Emily Carrasco Perez, Ibelis Feliciano, Lisette Flor, Nila Freeman, Lena Harrison, Jenny Hernandez, Chloe Hwang, Brianna Mariconda, Hannah Michelson, Yanilda Munoz, Yan Bing Tan 
   
 Divergence of Reactions  led by Professor Genevieve Lowe 
   
 Divergence of Reactions  shares works made by a diverse group of growing artists. The artists cover a wide range of topics in their work, bravely sharing emotional themes such as anxiety, depression, and different forms of abuse. Additional elements the work addresses include beauty, sportsmanship, fragility of life and more - giving viewers a window into the artists personal experiences. 
   
 Students: Ofelia Alves, David Arrigoni, Anandria Campbell, Kalee Chaudhry, Kaitlyn Ferguson, Andrew Frazier, Keith Melendez, Bridget Perez, Stanley Piercin, Shyeann Rapley, Francois Rivero, Swetha Sivakumar, Sam Wortche 
   
 Integrative Studio II Student-led Exhibition Finley Gallery, Finley Hall Exhibition dates: Feb 24– March 3, 2026 Opening Reception: Tuesday, Feb 24, 2026, 3:00pm–4:30pm

title: Art Forum Speaker Series featuring Alumni Panel: Nancy Pantirer ’80, Tiffany Perez ’09, and Maria Valdivia ’24
description:
The Department of Art & Design presents the Spring 2026 Art Forum series. Art Forum is a speaker series featuring artists, designers, art historians, curators, and art critics from around the world presenting their work and ideas in an open forum.   
   
 Next in this series is actually a multi-generational panel celebrating the distinguished women alumni of Montclair State University. Featuring exhibiting artists Nancy Pantirer ’80, Tiffany Perez ’09, and Maria Valdivia ’24, in conversation about their careers and creative practices, moderated by curator Sally Morgan Lehman. 
   
 Montclair State University celebrates the creative achievements of its alumni with  Carpe Diem: Select Alumni in the Visual Arts , a group exhibition presented by the Office of Alumni Engagement and Development and hosted by the University Galleries.  Carpe Diem  brings together the works of twelve accomplished artists whose work spans figurative and abstract painting, photography, mixed media, video and installation. The exhibition is on view February 3 through May 3 in the George Segal Gallery. 
   
 Curated by Sally Morgan Lehman, who has taught in the Department of Art and Design at Montclair and is owner and director of Morgan Lehman Gallery in New York City, Carpe Diem highlights the breadth of artistic practices fostered at Montclair and the lasting impact of its visual arts alumni. 
   
 Nancy Pantirer ’80 is a New York-based artist working primarily in large-scale abstract painting. Through abstraction, Pantirer invokes an ongoing dialogue between control and order versus freedom and randomness. Pantirer holds a Bachelor of Fine Arts from the Hartford Art School at the University of Hartford, as well as a Master of Arts from Montclair State College. She further refined her craft through graduate coursework at Tufts University Museum School in Boston and Pratt University in New York. Her painting and sculpture have been exhibited throughout the country and can be found in collections such as the University of Hartford, as well as in corporate and private collections. Her studio is located in Tribeca, New York City, where she also founded 81 Leonard Gallery to uplift local emerging artists. 
   
 Tiffany Perez ’09 is a New Jersey-based artist whose work bridges realism and culture, exploring themes of connection and inviting viewers to engage with pieces that feel familiar, nostalgic, and deeply at home. A lifelong creator—she began drawing at age two—Tiffany studied advertising arts at Passaic County Technical Institute and later earned her BFA in Fine Arts (Drawing) from Montclair State University. Her practice spans tattooing, pottery, textured painting, and realism, but her featured series for this exhibition focuses on color-pencil Moka Pots—symbolic pieces inspired by heritage and the shared comfort of home. Through familiar objects and rich detail, Tiffany creates art that resonates, invites reflection, and brings warmth into living spaces. She is also the owner of Ink Gallery Tattoo Studio in Fairfield, NJ, continuing her mission to create and uplift the community through art and tattoos.  
   
 Maria Valdivia ’24 is a painter dedicated to shining a spotlight on the often overlooked and under-appreciated aspects of people. Drawing inspiration from everyday people and community life, Maria’s artwork celebrates the unique qualities in the human body. She skillfully captures the essence of her subjects, inviting viewers to pause and reflect on the beauty and resilience found in the ordinary. Maria’s paintings serve as portals into the rich inner worlds of her subjects, encouraging viewers to bring their own interpretations and emotions to complete her evocative compositions. 
   
 Together, they represent multiple generations of Red Hawks who shape the local, national and international creative landscape as artists, educators and cultural leaders.

title: Beyond the Hype: Preparing for an AI-driven Workplace
location: University Hall 7th Floor, Montclair State University
description:
On  Monday, March 2nd , the MBA and Graduate Programs Office will host our Spring 2026 Executive Speaker Series and we are excited to welcome  Jack Hanlon, a Product Leader at Meta . In this role, he leads teams that develop state of the art generative AI models and translate them into products to benefit Meta’s 3.5B+ global users. 
 This engaging interview-style discussion titled, " Beyond the Hype: Preparing for an AI-Driven Workplace"  will be facilitated by Michael Hacker, Director of SBUS Technology Support Services at Montclair State University Feliciano School of Business. This is a unique opportunity for students to gain valuable insights into Mr. Hanlon’s career journey and hear firsthand perspectives on the impact of AI on day-to-day business functions, leadership, strategic decision-making, and the evolving business landscape. 
 Details of the event are as follows: 
 Light Dinner and Reception - 5:30 PM Presentation - 6:00 PM Q&A - 6:45-7:00 PM University Hall Conference Center - 7th Floor

title: A Cross-Generational Conversation with Alumni Artists
location: George Segal Gallery, 4th Floor of the Red Hawk Deck
description:
Admission is free, open to the public.  Learn more about this exhibition 
   
 This multi-generational panel celebrates the distinguished women alumni of Montclair. Featuring exhibiting artists Nancy Bergman Pantirer ’80, Tiffany Perez ’09, and Maria Valdivia ’24 in conversation about their careers and creative practices, moderated by curator Sally Morgan Lehman. 
   
 Carpe Diem: Select Alumni in the Visual Arts  is a group exhibition presented by the Office for Development and Alumni Engagement and hosted by the University Galleries.  Carpe Diem  brings together twelve accomplished alumni working in a range of media. 
   
 Curated by Sally Morgan Lehman, who has taught in the Department of Art and Design at Montclair and is owner and director of Morgan Lehman Gallery in New York City,  Carpe Diem  highlights the breadth of artistic practices fostered at Montclair and the lasting impact of its visual arts alumni. 
   
 Featured artists include Flávia Berindoague ’13, Bisa Butler ’05, Jonathan Calm ’97, Kyle Coniglio ’10, Alyssa Fanning ’12, Allen Ginsberg (1943), Márta Kucsora (2005–06), Michael Manning ’11, Nancy Bergman Pantirer ’80, Tiffany Perez ’09, William Pope.L ’78, and Maria Valdivia ’24.

title: Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art & Design is delighted to announce the Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibitions for the Spring 2026 semester. The exhibition will be presented in Finley Gallery & the adjoining Annex Galleries from February 24th through March 3rd, with a public reception on February 24th from 3:00pm until 4:30pm. 
   
 The ISII exhibition is the culmination of a six-week journey shared by visual arts majors across two sections of Integrative Studio II. Using the piñata as a point of origin for their investigation, the artists delved deeply into the subject to expand their understanding of its history, materiality, and cultural significance. Building on this initial research, they created artworks across media exploring a range of themes, including construction, deconstruction, regeneration, and transformation. The artists themselves collectively organized this public sharing of their work—together they met the challenge of presenting a visual through line within the shared gallery spaces while still highlighting the unique voices of each class, as reflected by the two exhibition subtitles:  From the Outside In , and  Divergence of Reactions .  
   
 From the Outside In  led by Professor Jess Blaustein 
   
 From the Outside In  features diverse works of thirteen artists from Integrative Studio 2, providing an intimate glimpse into their personal memories, emotions, and cultural backgrounds. From larger than life to up close and personal, these exceptional works touch upon the wondrous human experience on a whole new level. 
   
 Students: Marley Balkau, Sandra Benlian, Emily Carrasco Perez, Ibelis Feliciano, Lisette Flor, Nila Freeman, Lena Harrison, Jenny Hernandez, Chloe Hwang, Brianna Mariconda, Hannah Michelson, Yanilda Munoz, Yan Bing Tan 
   
 Divergence of Reactions  led by Professor Genevieve Lowe 
   
 Divergence of Reactions  shares works made by a diverse group of growing artists. The artists cover a wide range of topics in their work, bravely sharing emotional themes such as anxiety, depression, and different forms of abuse. Additional elements the work addresses include beauty, sportsmanship, fragility of life and more - giving viewers a window into the artists personal experiences. 
   
 Students: Ofelia Alves, David Arrigoni, Anandria Campbell, Kalee Chaudhry, Kaitlyn Ferguson, Andrew Frazier, Keith Melendez, Bridget Perez, Stanley Piercin, Shyeann Rapley, Francois Rivero, Swetha Sivakumar, Sam Wortche 
   
 Integrative Studio II Student-led Exhibition Finley Gallery, Finley Hall Exhibition dates: Feb 24– March 3, 2026 Opening Reception: Tuesday, Feb 24, 2026, 3:00pm–4:30pm

 Panelists 
 Elaine Meryl Brown: Daytime Emmy® Award-winning writer and former HBO media executive, Elaine reflects on her experience within the media and entertainment industry empowering Black women through her book The Next Little Black Book of Success. 
 Catherine Sackey: Policy Strategist, Systems Architect, Founder and CEO of POP Consulting, Catherine works to inspire women on their professional journeys. 
 Gladys Vonglahn: Originally from Chile, and a first-generation college student, Gladys is a determined and visionary leader as well as an expert on economic progress, entrepreneurship, self-esteem and personal improvement.

title: The DJ Academy: Music Matters 101
description:
DJing is one of the original elements of Hip Hop and is often considered the first. Hip Hop began in the Bronx during the 1970s at community block parties, where DJs used turntables to bring people together through music. Early pioneers like DJ Kool Herc introduced breakbeats by looping the most rhythmic parts of records, creating the foundation for breaking and shaping how dancers and MCs interacted with the music. 
 As Hip Hop evolved, DJing became the musical backbone of the culture. DJs provide the beats for MCing, set the tempo for dancers, and control the energy of Hip Hop spaces by reading the crowd and responding in real time. Through techniques like scratching, cutting, and beat juggling, DJs helped define Hip Hop’s sound while preserving its history and passing down cultural knowledge. 
 This class introduces the basics of DJing and how music shapes the dance experience. DJ Bascis will explain core concepts such as  tempo, rhythm, and song structure , helping students understand how music guides movement and energy on the dance floor. 
 Participants will learn how DJs choose music, create smooth transitions, and adjust the vibe based on the room.  
 Through simple examples and live demonstrations, students will build confidence in listening to music with intention. This can bewhether they are dancing, freestyling, or interested in DJing themselves. 
 This class is designed for  beginners and college students , with no prior DJ or music experience required.

title: INNOVATION NATION: KNOWLEDGE, DISCOVERY, AND THE AMERICAN EMERGENCE
location: Presentation Hall (College of Communication and Media)
description: Scientific inquiry, intellectual property and innovation have played a pivotal role in shaping America’s economic growth, security, and democratic aspirations. From early patent law and land-grant universities to federally funded research and the modern innovation economy, this lecture explores how public policy has structured incentives for discovery and dissemination of knowledge. Particular attention is given to universities as engines of research, talent development, and public purpose, operating at the intersection of academic freedom and national priorities. Participants will be asked to consider how evolving partnerships between government and higher education advance the common good and fuel America’s capacity for innovation.

title: Department of Theatre and Dance | Passage '26
description:
TICKETS: $25 |$30 includes a $5 per ticket handling fee when ordering online 
 A fantasia inspired by E.M. Forster’s novel A Passage to India, PASSAGE is set in the fictional Country X, which is a neocolonial client of Country Y. A local doctor from Country X and a visiting teacher from Country Y begin to forge a friendship that is challenged after a fateful trip to a local attraction, exposing the complexities of cultural misunderstanding and power imbalances. A meditation on colonization, the mutability of political borders, and the elusive nature of true understanding. 
 This production of  Passage  is recommended for ages 16+ for mature themes and profanity. LATE SEATING - DISCRETION OF THE HOUSE MANAGER

At this meeting, we’ll cover important information about living in Bohn Hall, including community expectations, resources, and ways to get involved. 
 Residents will also have the chance to ask questions, share feedback, and meet others in the building. Attendance is encouraged to stay up-to-date and make the most out of your living experience on campus. 
 What to Expect: 
 
 Resources and support available to you 
 Opportunities to connect with staff and peers 
 A chance to ask questions and share your voice 
 
 We look forward to seeing you there! 
 This event is for Bohn Hall Residents

title: Tri Sigma New Member Education
location: University Hall 1030 - Charlotte Roome Shotmeyer Lecture Hall
description: A New Member Education (NME) meeting is a structured gathering designed to help new members learn about Tri Sigma’s history, values, traditions, and expectations. During these meetings, new members build connections with one another, develop leadership and personal growth skills, and gain a deeper understanding of what it means to be a lifelong member of the organization. NME meetings create a supportive environment where new members can ask questions, reflect on their experiences, and prepare for initiation while strengthening their sense of belonging within the chapter.

title: upLIFT
description:
Step into the brand-new PLAE Room and discover upLIFT—a judgement-free program designed to help every student, from complete beginners to seasoned gym-goers, feel confident and capable with free-weight training. Learn proper lifting technique, get personalized form checks, and master the basics of creating your own effective workout programs. Whether you’re looking to meet other students who love to lift, pursue new fitness goals, or simply feel more at home in the weight room, upLIFT offers a supportive community and a dedicated space to grow. The program is structured for steady progression throughout the semester, but you’re welcome to drop in anytime and join at your own pace. 
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 No registration required 
 FREE for students with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 Where and when? 
 
 Beginning February 3, ending April 23 
 Tuesdays 3 PM - 4 PM, Wednesdays 6 PM - 7 PM, and Thursdays 2 PM - 3 PM 
 Student Recreation Center PLAE Room

title: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People Weekly Discussion
organization: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People
description:
NAACP is back for Spring 2026—and we’re leveling up.  Every  Thursday from 3:30–4:45 PM , tap in for weekly discussions that spark conversation, inspire change, and build community. 
 From  civil rights and mental health to campus advocacy and organizing , each week features a new topic rooted in the NAACP’s mission. Whether you want to speak up, listen, or just vibe with like-minded students, this is your space. Come as you are—everyone belongs here. 🖤

title: Free Swim Lessons *Intermediate*
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Thursday: 4-5PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Thursday: 4-5PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Wise Women: Humanities Untold Origins - Documentary Screening and Panel
organization: College of Humanities and Social Sciences (CHSS)
description:
What if everything we’ve been taught about aging – especially for women – needs a rewrite? 
   
 You’re invited to a free, exclusive screening of the documentary Wise Women that flips the script on beauty, power, and visibility. Featuring the filmmakers and special guests, this is more than just a film screening – it’s a thought-provoking conversation you’ll want to be in the room for. 
   
 Thursday, 3/5, 6:00-8:30pm Feliciano School of Business SBUS 140 Please RSVP:  https://www.weareplannedparenthood.org/a/wise-women-march-26 
   
 Presented in partnership between the Montclair State University Gender, Sexuality, and Women’s Studies Program and the Planned Parenthood of Metropolitan New Jersey

title: Department of Theatre and Dance | Passage '26
description:
TICKETS: $25 |$30 includes a $5 per ticket handling fee when ordering online 
 A fantasia inspired by E.M. Forster’s novel A Passage to India, PASSAGE is set in the fictional Country X, which is a neocolonial client of Country Y. A local doctor from Country X and a visiting teacher from Country Y begin to forge a friendship that is challenged after a fateful trip to a local attraction, exposing the complexities of cultural misunderstanding and power imbalances. A meditation on colonization, the mutability of political borders, and the elusive nature of true understanding. 
 This production of  Passage  is recommended for ages 16+ for mature themes and profanity. LATE SEATING - DISCRETION OF THE HOUSE MANAGER 
 Tickets

title: Cru Large Group!
description:
Cru is a caring community passionate about connecting people to Jesus Christ!  Join us in learning together on Who Christ is, building a personal relationship with Him, and joining a community filled with love and open arms!  
 This semester, we will be focusing on the theme  "Identity in Christ."  We pray that our students will learn more about who they are in Christ, and look at some examples of people in the Bible where God revealed their true identity in Christ! 
 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC | Atlantic Brass Quintet Masterclass
description:
Atlantic Brass Quintet Masterclass FREE and Open to the Public Reservations not required 
 The  Atlantic Brass Quintet  performs the uniquely American music of composer  Jeff Scott , and will coach Cali School brass ensembles in a masterclass setting. 
 Widely acclaimed as one of the world's finest and most versatile brass chamber ensembles, the  Atlantic Brass Quintet  has performed in 48 of the United States and dozens of countries across four continents. Atlantic specializes in masterful and vibrant presentations of repertoire spanning five centuries and a broad spectrum of styles, from artistic transcription of baroque music to the lively music of Balkan brass bands. Winner of six international chamber music competitions, the Quintet's distinctive sound, impeccable ensemble, stunning virtuosity, and warm, inviting stage presence have won praise from scores of critics.

title: Clinical Psychology (MA) Virtual Information Session
description:
Transform Lives With A Career In Clinical Psychology 
 Montclair's Clinical Psychology program combines advanced education with practical experience. Whether you’re interested in working in private practice or research, we’ll walk you through the wide range of career paths available for clinical psychology graduates. We offer two  STEM-Designated  concentrations within our rigorous Master's program, tailored to your unique practice objectives: 
 
 Clinical Psychology, Child/Adolescent Psychology Concentration (MA) Students in the child/adolescent concentration learn about the unique psychological needs of children and adolescents, as well as developmental considerations in psychopathology, assessment, and treatment, including the role of family and social contexts. This concentration is designed to prepare students for MA-level clinical positions in mental health settings, particularly those that serve children and families.    
 Clinical Psychology, Forensic Psychology Concentration (MA) The Forensic Psychology concentration is designed to prepare students to offer master’s level clinical services to legal system-involved populations in settings that do not require licensure. Such settings include mental health and drug court settings, offender rehabilitation programs, child and family advocacy settings and bona fide public service agencies exempted by state boards of psychological examiners for non-doctoral providers. 
 
 Ready to learn more? Join us for a  virtual information session on March 9 at 5:30 PM (EST)  to explore Montclair's programs in Clinical Psychology and speak directly with our faculty.

title: Caribbean Students' Organization: General body Meetings
description: CaribSO’s General Body Meetings provide an open and welcoming space for students to connect, engage, and learn about Caribbean culture and community. These meetings are used to share important updates, plan upcoming events, discuss organizational initiatives, and encourage member involvement. General body meetings promote leadership development, collaboration, and cultural awareness while fostering a strong sense of community among members.

title: Kirby Airiders Hangout
description: Get ready to race and compete in this chaos filled party racer featuring Kirby and Friends. Join Game Club this afternoon as we play Kirby Airriders Races and City Trial.

title: NASO General Body Meeting
description: Join us for the Native African Student Organization's General Body Meeting! This is a space where we come together to celebrate and explore the richness of African cultures, while also connecting with other cultures from around the world. At each meeting, we'll engage in lively discussions, learn about Africa’s diverse history, traditions, and current events, and empower each other to understand and embrace our heritage. Whether you're looking to deepen your cultural knowledge, make meaningful connections, or simply have fun with fellow students who share a passion for Africa and global cultures, this is the place to be! Let’s build a supportive community, amplify African voices on campus, and create lasting friendships. All are welcome, come, learn, share, and connect!

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC | Ukrainian Contemporary Music Festival at Montclair State University
description:
Ukrainian Contemporary Music Festival at Montclair State University 
 Inaugural Montclair State University presentation of the only festival in North America dedicated to showcasing Ukraine's complex and diverse contributions to contemporary music. 
 Concert fearturing Montclair State University Faculty, students and a  special guest  The Rhythm  Method Quartet 
 The Rhythm Method is a quartet of composer-performers reimagining the string quartet through a contemporary, intersectional feminist lens—collaborating closely with composers, blending improvisation and notation, amplifying marginalized voices, and fostering collective creativity through performance and education. 
 All are welcome.  Reservations are not necessary.

title: ⭐ Honor Society Info Sessions (ALD, NSCS, Tau Sigma)
description: A Prestigious Scholarship is an academic or financial award given to outstanding students for graduate programs nationally and internationally. These scholarships often come with significant financial benefits, including full or partial tuition coverage, stipends for living expenses, and sometimes additional funds for research or travel. Join us to learn more about upcoming Prestigious Scholarship opportunities for the 2025-26 academic year.

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Brief Description:  
 Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Free Swim Lessons *Intermediate*
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Evaluating Sources
description:
Join our workshop to learn the art of evaluating sources. Learn to discern credible sources, spot bias, and assess the strengths, weaknesses, and/or limitations of information sources. Gain critical thinking skills vital for academic success and informed lifelong decision-making.

Whether you want to stay as close to home as Pennsylvania or travel as far away as South Korea, Montclair State University has programs for you.

description: This overview will help familiarize you with MLA citations—an important part of academic writing in areas of the humanities such as English, Foreign Language and Literatures, Literary Criticism, and Cultural Studies. We will also review updates included in the 9th edition. Bring your Works Cited pages and questions for extra help .

 Our Mission:   We aim to address food insecurity across Montclair State University. The Red Hawk Pantry is open to all students, staff, faculty, and Alumni at no cost. If you are unable to visit during our regular hours, please reach out via email at redhawkpantry@montclair.edu Stay updated by following us on Instagram: @montclair_redhawkpantry

organization: The Historical Society at Montclair State
description: History Club invites students to a presentation exploring the history of St. Patrick’s Day and how it developed from a religious observance into a widely celebrated cultural holiday. The program will examine its Irish roots, traditions, and evolving meaning in the United States.

description: Join the Student Government Association for a constitutional meeting where we discuss campus business including, but not limited to, programming events, community service initiatives, improvements of student life, leadership, and engagement. Welcome to all students, faulty, and staff. Your voice matters here on our campus. Great things happen in small rooms. Meet us in the  Room of Excellence  at  Talbott Hall ,  every other Monday  at  2pm .

All are welcome, whether you have the most craft experience possible or none at all. Come by and enjoy the company of others who share your passions for the fiber arts!

location: University Hall 1020 - Bard-Blount Family Lecture Hall
description: A New Member Education (NME) meeting is a structured gathering designed to help new members learn about Tri Sigma’s history, values, traditions, and expectations. NME meetings create a supportive environment where new members can ask questions, reflect on their experiences, and prepare for initiation while strengthening their sense of belonging within the chapter.

title: Major & Career Exploration Talks: What We Wish We Knew Before Declaring!
description:
Not sure what major to choose or where your career path is headed? You’re not alone! Join us for Major & Career Exploration Talks: What We Wish We Knew Before Declaring!, a dynamic panel event where upperclassmen students share their real, unfiltered experiences about choosing their majors and navigating their career journeys. Hear firsthand what they wish they knew before declaring, the challenges they faced, and how they found their passions. Whether you're feeling undecided, overwhelmed, or just curious about different paths, this event will give you insights, inspiration, and practical advice to help you make informed decisions. Don’t miss this opportunity to gain valuable perspectives and take the next step in your academic and career journey! * Food and refreshments will be served! 
 Event Details: 📅 Date: March 17, 2026 🕒 Time: 2:30pm - 3:30pm 📍 Location: Student Center Underground (Rm 160) 
 Presented by the University College Academic Programming Team

title: upLIFT
description:
Step into the brand-new PLAE Room and discover upLIFT—a judgement-free program designed to help every student, from complete beginners to seasoned gym-goers, feel confident and capable with free-weight training. Learn proper lifting technique, get personalized form checks, and master the basics of creating your own effective workout programs. Whether you’re looking to meet other students who love to lift, pursue new fitness goals, or simply feel more at home in the weight room, upLIFT offers a supportive community and a dedicated space to grow. The program is structured for steady progression throughout the semester, but you’re welcome to drop in anytime and join at your own pace. 
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 No registration required 
 FREE for students with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 Where and when? 
 
 Beginning February 3, ending April 23 
 Tuesdays 3 PM - 4 PM, Wednesdays 6 PM - 7 PM, and Thursdays 2 PM - 3 PM

title: The DJ Academy: Music Matters 101
description:
DJing is one of the original elements of Hip Hop and is often considered the first. Hip Hop began in the Bronx during the 1970s at community block parties, where DJs used turntables to bring people together through music. Early pioneers like DJ Kool Herc introduced breakbeats by looping the most rhythmic parts of records, creating the foundation for breaking and shaping how dancers and MCs interacted with the music. 
 As Hip Hop evolved, DJing became the musical backbone of the culture. DJs provide the beats for MCing, set the tempo for dancers, and control the energy of Hip Hop spaces by reading the crowd and responding in real time. Through techniques like scratching, cutting, and beat juggling, DJs helped define Hip Hop’s sound while preserving its history and passing down cultural knowledge. 
 This class introduces the basics of DJing and how music shapes the dance experience. DJ Bascis will explain core concepts such as  tempo, rhythm, and song structure , helping students understand how music guides movement and energy on the dance floor. 
 Participants will learn how DJs choose music, create smooth transitions, and adjust the vibe based on the room.  
 Through simple examples and live demonstrations, students will build confidence in listening to music with intention. This can bewhether they are dancing, freestyling, or interested in DJing themselves. 
 This class is designed for  beginners and college students , with no prior DJ or music experience required.

title: Safe Space Training
description:
Our Safe Space Training is an intensive, interactive training that provides attendees with information and tools to combat homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, cissexism and heterosexism, on campus and beyond. Through interactive activities and discussion, participants will personally reflect on their own experiences to enhance their personal and professional development, provide further education, and finally, identify ways to create change on campus and beyond. 
 All sessions are three hours and are first-come, first-served. Pre-registration is required. Registrants are expected to attend the full session. Only individuals who have fully completed the Safe Space Program and have agreed to the expectations of its membership are able to display the sticker/button of our program. Refreshments are not provided; however, you are more than welcome to bring your lunch, coffee, snacks, etc.

title: Higher Education (MA) Virtual Information Session
description:
Build your career in Higher Education    
 Whether you're already working in  higher ed  or looking to break into the field, our flexible program is designed to meet you where you are - and help you go even further. 
 We're hosting a  virtual information session on March 19  at 6:00 PM . This is a no-pressure, exploratory space to meet our team and determine if our program fits your goals. 
 Our coursework offers a broad focus on administration and leadership, preparing students for a variety of roles in higher education. The curriculum integrates organizational and social science perspectives and explores key administrative and programmatic issues.

title: Child Advocacy (MA) Alumni Perspectives: Advocating for Children in 2026
description:
Lead Change in Child Advocacy and Policy   When children and families face complex challenges, they need informed, compassionate professionals to stand up, speak out, and shape solutions. If you're ready to turn your commitment into action, we're here to help.  We're hosting a  virtual panel featuring alumni from our program on March 19 at 6:00 PM (EST) . This is a no-pressure, exploratory space to hear directly from professionals who were once in your shoes and determine if our program fits your goals. This session will cover the following programs:  
 
 Online Master of Arts in Child Advocacy and Policy 
 Child Advocacy (Certificate) – Online 
 
 Why Montclair?  Completing the certificate program allows you to transfer all 15 credits towards the Master of Arts in Child Advocacy, in accordance with all related graduate policy.

title: Cru Large Group!
description:
Cru is a caring community passionate about connecting people to Jesus Christ!  Join us in learning together on Who Christ is, building a personal relationship with Him, and joining a community filled with love and open arms!  
 This semester, we will be focusing on the theme  "Identity in Christ."  We pray that our students will learn more about who they are in Christ, and look at some examples of people in the Bible where God revealed their true identity in Christ! 
 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSiC |  Masterclass with Kyle Resnick
description:
Masterclass with Kyle Resnick 
 Free and Open to the Public, Reservations not Required 
 Join the brass area for a very special masterclass with trumpeter  Kyle Resnick . Kyle will work with Cali students and share what he's learned on his incredible musical journey that has seen him performing and recording with  Taylor Swift, Ed Sheeran, Bruce Springsteen, Beirut, The National,  and  Mumford and Sons,  among others! 
 Bio: 
 Kyle Resnick  is a trumpet player known for his versatility and contributions to both live performances and studio recordings across a wide variety of genres and musical styles. He has established himself as a prominent figure in the music industry through collaborations with a diverse array of artists and groups, from recording for Taylor Swift (“Folklore,” “Evermore,” and “Midnights”), Ed Sheeran and Bruce Springsteen, among several others, to Classical chamber and solo and countless orchestral performances on concert stages over three decades. He has felt equally at home on stages like Carnegie Hall, Lincoln Center, the Barbican, Royal Albert Hall, Sydney Opera House and venues such as the Hollywood Bowl, and arenas and stadiums around the globe. Kyle is a longstanding touring and recording member of the bands The National and Beirut, and has commenced in 2025 on a world tour with the band Mumford & Sons, for which he has also recorded on the last two albums. Since his time as a student to the present day, Kyle has found great satisfaction enriching his musical journey through teaching trumpet and directing ensembles, having served on the faculties of Juilliard Pre-College, Brooklyn College, SUNY University at Buffalo and SUNY Buffalo State.

title: Worship Night (Campus Invasion)
location: Student Center 250BC - Ballrooms B and C
description:
Campus Invasion  is a night set apart to lift up the name of Jesus at Montclair State University. On March 20th, we gather not just for music, but for worship—creating space for God’s presence to move freely among us. 
 This night is an invitation to pause from the busyness of campus life, lay down distractions, and come before God with open hearts. We believe worship is more than a song; it is surrender, alignment, and response to who God is. As we worship together, we are trusting God to refresh weary hearts, restore hope, and awaken a deeper hunger for Him. 
 Campus Invasion is about unity—students, friends, and the campus community coming together to seek God, pray, and declare Jesus as Lord over our lives and our campus. Whether you’ve been walking with God for years or you’re simply curious and searching, this night is for you. 
 Come expectant. Come ready to worship. Come as you are. Jesus will be glorified.

title: Balsam Lake Mountain Hike
description:
Take in classic Catskill views on this scenic hike to  Balsam Lake Mountain  via the  Dry Brook Ridge Trail  in the Balsam Lake Mountain Wild Forest. This moderately rated  6-mile out-and-back hike  features a steady climb with  1,197 feet of elevation gain , winding through hardwood forests before reaching the summit. At the top, hikers are rewarded with sweeping mountain views and a historic fire tower that offers a perfect spot to rest, refuel, and soak it all in. This trail is ideal for hikers looking for a solid challenge with a big payoff. 
 How do I sign up? 
 
 Register in the Student Recreation Center main office or over the phone (973-655-3340). 
 Cost for Students $10 / Faculty, Staff $20 
 
 Where and when? 
 
 Saturday, March 21, 2026 
 10:00 a.m. – 5:00 p.m. 
 Begins at the Student Recreation Center 
 
 What to bring: Water, lunch/snacks, sunscreen, bug spray, layered clothing (depending on weather), sturdy close-toe hiking shoes or boots 
 Potential Hazards: Uneven and rocky terrain; steep sections; slippery surfaces (especially if wet); sudden weather changes; sun exposure; dehydration; insect bites; poisonous plants/allergies; wildlife encounters; and injuries including sprains/strains, abrasions, lacerations, and fractures.

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Brief Description:  
 Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Free Swim Lessons *Intermediate*
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up?

title: GOVERNING BEYOND ELECTIONS: ACCOUNTABILITY, PROSPERITY AND THE AMERICAN ADMINISTRATIVE STATE
location: Presentation Hall (College of Communication and Media)
description: The emergence of a highly competent bureaucracy is typically under appreciated, if not ignored, as an ingredient in the emergence of the American experiment. While government administrators are often derided as inefficient or even obstructionist, technocrats are responsible for making government work and offer policy continuity and expertise across administrations. Still, the growth of a large permanent bureaucracy challenges the notion of accountability grounded in democratic elections. By tracing historical developments and contemporary debates, this lecture focuses on the centrality of government administrative capacity in the American experiment, focusing on the tensions and collaboration between elected officials and professional bureaucrats. We will consider the role of independent government agencies that were established with the idea of partitioning regulatory functions from partisan pressure.

title: 2026 Class Gift Tabling - Information and Philanthropy Cord Pick-Up
description:
Each year, our graduating class participates in a proud Class Gift tradition where members of the class invest in the University by supporting areas of Montclair State University that are most important to them. We invite the Class of 2026 to come together to show your support! 
 All gifts to Montclair count! Make your gift to any area of campus you feel most passionate about – such as the Emergency Book Fund, The Red Hawk Pantry, your school or college, The Fund for Montclair State or athletic program. 
 Your gift will pay it forward for future Red Hawks and kick-start your philanthropic connection to Montclair. 
 
 Commemorate your class year! Make a gift of at least  $20.26  and you’ll receive your customized philanthropy cord to wear over your commencement robe.  
 For a gift of  $40 , celebrate this milestone with your family, friends and colleagues by having your message displayed on the screen at the Commencement you will be participating in, and receive a customized philanthropy cord. 
 
 How do I get my customized philanthropy cord? 
 Customized philanthropy cords will be available for pick-up: 
 
 Tuesday, October 28 from 1:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Thursday, November 20  from 1:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Tuesday, December 2 from 12:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Bloomfield Campus Graduation Fair: Wednesday, December 10th from 12:00 – 6:00 p.m. in Deacon’s Den, Talbott Hall  (for Bloomfield graduates only) 
 Montclair Campus Graduation Fairs: Thursday, December 11th from 10:00 a.m. – 7:00 p.m. in the Student Center Ballrooms  (for Montclair or Bloomfield graduates) 
 
 Graduates can also arrange to pick up their philanthropy cords in the Overlook Corporate Center, 150 Clove Road, Little Falls, NJ during business hours, Monday through Friday, 8:30 a.m. – 4:30 p.m. Philanthropy cords can also be mailed to those who cannot pick it up. The last day we will mail the cords is Monday, December 22, 2025 at 2:30 p.m. Please contact James Stewart, Associate Director of Annual Giving at stewartj@montclair.edu or 973-655-5328 to finalize options to get your cords for the Winter Commencement. 
 Every student has benefitted from donor generosity to areas of academic support, emergency funding for students and overall priorities to boost students’ success every day. Thank you for paying it forward! For more information, please contact James Stewart, Associate Director of Annual Giving, at 973-655-5328 or stewartj@montclair.edu.

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

This is a space where we come together to celebrate and explore the richness of African cultures, while also connecting with other cultures from around the world. At each meeting, we'll engage in lively discussions, learn about Africa’s diverse history, traditions, and current events, and empower each other to understand and embrace our heritage. Whether you're looking to deepen your cultural knowledge, make meaningful connections, or simply have fun with fellow students who share a passion for Africa and global cultures, this is the place to be! Let’s build a supportive community, amplify African voices on campus, and create lasting friendships. All are welcome, come, learn, share, and connect!

title: The DJ Academy: Music Matters 101
description:
DJing is one of the original elements of Hip Hop and is often considered the first. Hip Hop began in the Bronx during the 1970s at community block parties, where DJs used turntables to bring people together through music. Early pioneers like DJ Kool Herc introduced breakbeats by looping the most rhythmic parts of records, creating the foundation for breaking and shaping how dancers and MCs interacted with the music. 
 As Hip Hop evolved, DJing became the musical backbone of the culture. DJs provide the beats for MCing, set the tempo for dancers, and control the energy of Hip Hop spaces by reading the crowd and responding in real time. Through techniques like scratching, cutting, and beat juggling, DJs helped define Hip Hop’s sound while preserving its history and passing down cultural knowledge. 
 This class introduces the basics of DJing and how music shapes the dance experience. DJ Bascis will explain core concepts such as  tempo, rhythm, and song structure , helping students understand how music guides movement and energy on the dance floor. 
 Participants will learn how DJs choose music, create smooth transitions, and adjust the vibe based on the room.  
 Through simple examples and live demonstrations, students will build confidence in listening to music with intention. This can bewhether they are dancing, freestyling, or interested in DJing themselves. 
 This class is designed for  beginners and college students , with no prior DJ or music experience required.

title: Free Swim Lessons *Intermediate*
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Wednesday: 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: upLIFT
description:
Step into the brand-new PLAE Room and discover upLIFT—a judgement-free program designed to help every student, from complete beginners to seasoned gym-goers, feel confident and capable with free-weight training. Learn proper lifting technique, get personalized form checks, and master the basics of creating your own effective workout programs. Whether you’re looking to meet other students who love to lift, pursue new fitness goals, or simply feel more at home in the weight room, upLIFT offers a supportive community and a dedicated space to grow. The program is structured for steady progression throughout the semester, but you’re welcome to drop in anytime and join at your own pace. 
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 No registration required 
 FREE for students with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 Where and when? 
 
 Beginning February 3, ending April 23 
 Tuesdays 3 PM - 4 PM, Wednesdays 6 PM - 7 PM, and Thursdays 2 PM - 3 PM 
 Student Recreation Center PLAE Room

title: Tri Sigma New Member Education
location: University Hall 1030 - Charlotte Roome Shotmeyer Lecture Hall
description: A New Member Education (NME) meeting is a structured gathering designed to help new members learn about Tri Sigma’s history, values, traditions, and expectations. During these meetings, new members build connections with one another, develop leadership and personal growth skills, and gain a deeper understanding of what it means to be a lifelong member of the organization. NME meetings create a supportive environment where new members can ask questions, reflect on their experiences, and prepare for initiation while strengthening their sense of belonging within the chapter.

title: Educational Leadership Virtual Information Session: For M.A. (Online, Fast Track, Core Choice, Offsite) and Certification Programs for: Supervisor, Principal, Director of School Counseling Services
description:
Become the leader our schools need   If you’ve thought about the next step in your education career - whether that means becoming a principal, stepping into an admin role, or just making a bigger impact - we want to meet you.  Our Educational Leadership program is built for professionals like you who want to lead with purpose, create change, and shape the future of schools and students. We're hosting an  Educational Leadership (MA) Virtual Information Session March 26 at 5:00 PM (EST) . This is a no-pressure, exploratory space to meet our team and determine if our program fits your goals. This session will cover the following programs:  
 
 Educational Leadership (MA)   Online, Fast Track, Core Choice, and Offsite 
 Supervisor Certification 
 Principal Certification 
 Director of School Counseling Services Certification

title: Cru Large Group!
description:
Cru is a caring community passionate about connecting people to Jesus Christ!  Join us in learning together on Who Christ is, building a personal relationship with Him, and joining a community filled with love and open arms!  
 This semester, we will be focusing on the theme  "Identity in Christ."  We pray that our students will learn more about who they are in Christ, and look at some examples of people in the Bible where God revealed their true identity in Christ! 
 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC | Colin Carr Cello Masterclass
description:
Colin Carr Cello Masterclass 
 Internationally acclaimed cellist  Colin Carr,  renowned as a soloist, chamber musician, recording artist, and dedicated teacher, will visit the Cali School for a masterclass and share his insights into cello performance and musical artistry. 
 Bio 
 Colin Carr  appears throughout the world as a soloist, chamber musician, recording artist, and teacher. He has played with major orchestras worldwide, including the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra, The Philharmonia, Royal Philharmonic, BBC Symphony, the orchestras of Chicago, Los Angeles, Washington, Philadelphia, Montréal and all the major orchestras of Australia and New Zealand. Conductors with whom he has worked include Rattle, Gergiev, Dutoit, Elder, Skrowasczewski and Marriner. Chamber music plays an important role in his musical life. He is a frequent visitor to international festivals and has appeared often as a guest with the Guarneri and Emerson string quartets and with New York's Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. He has held teaching positions at the New England Conservatory and the Royal Academy of Music. St John’s College, Oxford created the post of “Musician in Residence” for him. Since 2002 he been a professor at Stony Brook University in New York.

title: Turkey Mountain Hike (Easy)
description:
Looking  for  a  nice  day  out  with  your  friends?  Join  us  on  an easy  hike  at Turkey Mountain in   Montville Township . This  5.4  mile  hike  offers multiple viewpoints, a waterfall, and an area to explore ruins of an old stone home! 
 
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 Register in the Student Recreation Center main office or over the phone (973-655-3340). 
 Cost for Students  $10 ; Faculty/Staffa $20 
 
   
 Where and when? 
 
 Sunday, March 29 2026 
 10 a.m. - 5 p.m. 
 Begins at Student Recreation Center 
 
   
 What to bring:  Water, Lunch, and Boots or Sneakers 
   
 Potential Hazards:  Unpredictable weather changes, sunburn/heat exhaustion, limited vision, dehydration, allergic reactions/poisonous plants, insect bites, and injury by running, including sprains, lacerations, abrasions and fractures.

title: ⭐ Honor Society Info Sessions (ALD, NSCS, Tau Sigma)
description: A Prestigious Scholarship is an academic or financial award given to outstanding students for graduate programs nationally and internationally. These scholarships often come with significant financial benefits, including full or partial tuition coverage, stipends for living expenses, and sometimes additional funds for research or travel. Join us to learn more about upcoming Prestigious Scholarship opportunities for the 2025-26 academic year.

title: Free Swim Lessons *Intermediate*
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Brief Description:  
 Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Patriotic Trivia (Bloomfield Campus)
description:
Stars, stripes, and some serious smarts! ????? Join us for  Patriotic Trivia , a fast-paced, fun-filled event where you can test your knowledge of U.S. history, government, iconic moments, and all things red, white, and blue! 
 Whether you’re a history buff or just in it for the fun, this is your chance to show off what you know, learn something new, and enjoy some friendly competition with fellow students, faculty, and staff. 
 From the Constitution to pop culture, the questions will keep you guessing—and prizes are up for grabs! Come solo or bring a team, and get ready for an exciting celebration of civic knowledge and national pride. 
 Think you’ve got what it takes? Let’s find out—one trivia question at a time! Stop by, enjoy some pizza and you might even win some really cool prizes

title: Study Abroad 101
description: Join the Office of International Academic Initiatives to learn about the Study Abroad Opportunities that Montclair State University has to offer. Learn about our different programs that are as short as one week up to an academic year as well as scholarship information. Whether you want to stay as close to home as Pennsylvania or travel as far away as South Korea, Montclair State University has programs for you.

title: Splice Up Your Life: Understanding Comma Splices
description: Commas and semicolons are among the trickie r  punctuation marks to master. Whether you are struggling to understand their purpose or just need a refresher, this workshop will cover when and where to use those pesky punctuation marks .

title: Montclair Unraveled General Body Meeting!
description:
Do you want to learn a new knitting or crochet pattern? Do you want to make a cool craft but can't pick one or figure out where to start? Then come to Montclair Unraveled!

All are welcome, whether you have the most craft experience possible or none at all. Come by and enjoy the company of others who share your passions for the fiber arts!

title: Bench Press and Squat Competition
description:
Spring Strength Shadow! Welcome back to our annual Bench Press & Squat Competition. Come and test power and show your gains. Each event will feature 5 reps max. Whether you're chasing PRs or just want to flex for fun, this event is for you! Bring your friends and your lifting straps, and see who can lift their way to the top prize! 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Data: March 30th 
 Time: 3pm - 6pm 
 Student Recreation Center, Plae Room 
 
 How are results scored 
 
 Maximum 5 repetitions  
 1 attempt per lift after a warm up set 
 Scoring calculation: Weight lifted x repetitions divided by body weight  
 Final score will be a total of both lifts combined  
 
 Prizes :  
 
 Will be given to the top 3 winners  
 Tier 1: Beat Headphone ,  Fitness Watch ,  Air Fryer  $100-$200 
 Tier 2:  Massage Gun ,  Meal Prep Kit ,  Pilates Kit  $50-$100 
 Tier 3:  Foam Roller Set ,  Liquid IV ,  Owala Water Bottle  $20-$50 
 
 Free T-shirts - limited supply so show up early to claim one!

title: Bohn Hall Community Meeting
description:
Join us for the Bohn Hall Community Meeting! This is your opportunity to connect with your Professional Staff, student staff, and fellow residents as we kick off the semester together. At this meeting, we’ll cover important information about living in Bohn Hall, including community expectations, resources, and ways to get involved. 
 Residents will also have the chance to ask questions, share feedback, and meet others in the building. Attendance is encouraged to stay up-to-date and make the most out of your living experience on campus. 
 What to Expect: 
 
 Resources and support available to you 
 Opportunities to connect with staff and peers 
 A chance to ask questions and share your voice 
 
 We look forward to seeing you there! 
 This event is for Bohn Hall Residents

description: A New Member Education (NME) meeting is a structured gathering designed to help new members learn about Tri Sigma’s history, values, traditions, and expectations. During these meetings, new members build connections with one another, develop leadership and personal growth skills, and gain a deeper understanding of what it means to be a lifelong member of the organization. NME meetings create a supportive environment where new members can ask questions, reflect on their experiences, and prepare for initiation while strengthening their sense of belonging within the chapter.
