title: upLIFT
description:
Step into the brand-new PLAE Room and discover upLIFT—a judgement-free program designed to help every student, from complete beginners to seasoned gym-goers, feel confident and capable with free-weight training. Learn proper lifting technique, get personalized form checks, and master the basics of creating your own effective workout programs. Whether you’re looking to meet other students who love to lift, pursue new fitness goals, or simply feel more at home in the weight room, upLIFT offers a supportive community and a dedicated space to grow. The program is structured for steady progression throughout the semester, but you’re welcome to drop in anytime and join at your own pace. 
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 No registration required 
 FREE for students with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 Where and when? 
 
 Beginning February 3, ending April 23 
 Tuesdays 3 PM - 4 PM, Wednesdays 6 PM - 7 PM, and Thursdays 2 PM - 3 PM 
 Student Recreation Center PLAE Room

title: APIC Flag Raising Ceremony
description:
Come join us in kicking off  Asian American & Pacific Islander (AAPI) Heritage Month  at Montclair State University on  Wednesday, April 1 at 12:00 p.m. at the Student Center Flag Poles  for a flag raising ceremony .   The Asian Pacific Islander Caucus (APIC) invites you to this ceremony to raise the flag in recognition and honor of the contributions that generations of AAPIs have made to American history, society and culture. 
   
 Also, enjoy the first ever  AAPI "Day" Market  on the same day Wednesday, April 1 from 11:00am to 2:00pm on the Student Center Quad.  
   
 If you have any question, please contact APIC at apic@montclair.edu.

Join the Polish Club for a fun and interactive cultural event celebrating Polish Easter traditions! Learn about the history and meaning behind Pisanki (traditional Polish Easter eggs), Śmigus-Dyngus, Easter baskets (Święconka), and other holiday customs. 
 Participants will have the opportunity to decorate their own fake eggs using colorful paints and patterns while enjoying a welcoming and creative atmosphere. This event is a great way to explore Polish culture, meet new people, and create a unique keepsake to take home.

title: The DJ Academy: Music Matters 101
description:
DJing is one of the original elements of Hip Hop and is often considered the first. Hip Hop began in the Bronx during the 1970s at community block parties, where DJs used turntables to bring people together through music. Early pioneers like DJ Kool Herc introduced breakbeats by looping the most rhythmic parts of records, creating the foundation for breaking and shaping how dancers and MCs interacted with the music. 
 As Hip Hop evolved, DJing became the musical backbone of the culture. DJs provide the beats for MCing, set the tempo for dancers, and control the energy of Hip Hop spaces by reading the crowd and responding in real time. Through techniques like scratching, cutting, and beat juggling, DJs helped define Hip Hop’s sound while preserving its history and passing down cultural knowledge. 
 This class introduces the basics of DJing and how music shapes the dance experience. DJ Bascis will explain core concepts such as  tempo, rhythm, and song structure , helping students understand how music guides movement and energy on the dance floor. 
 Participants will learn how DJs choose music, create smooth transitions, and adjust the vibe based on the room.  
 Through simple examples and live demonstrations, students will build confidence in listening to music with intention. This can bewhether they are dancing, freestyling, or interested in DJing themselves. 
 This class is designed for  beginners and college students , with no prior DJ or music experience required.

title: NASO General Body Meeting
description: Join us for the Native African Student Organization's General Body Meeting! This is a space where we come together to celebrate and explore the richness of African cultures, while also connecting with other cultures from around the world. At each meeting, we'll engage in lively discussions, learn about Africa’s diverse history, traditions, and current events, and empower each other to understand and embrace our heritage. Whether you're looking to deepen your cultural knowledge, make meaningful connections, or simply have fun with fellow students who share a passion for Africa and global cultures, this is the place to be! Let’s build a supportive community, amplify African voices on campus, and create lasting friendships. All are welcome, come, learn, share, and connect!

title: Cru Large Group!
description:
Cru is a caring community passionate about connecting people to Jesus Christ!  Join us in learning together on Who Christ is, building a personal relationship with Him, and joining a community filled with love and open arms!  
 This semester, we will be focusing on the theme  "Identity in Christ."  We pray that our students will learn more about who they are in Christ, and look at some examples of people in the Bible where God revealed their true identity in Christ! 
 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. title: Free Swim Lessons *Intermediate*
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Brief Description:  
 Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: upLIFT
description:
Step into the brand-new PLAE Room and discover upLIFT—a judgement-free program designed to help every student, from complete beginners to seasoned gym-goers, feel confident and capable with free-weight training. Learn proper lifting technique, get personalized form checks, and master the basics of creating your own effective workout programs. Whether you’re looking to meet other students who love to lift, pursue new fitness goals, or simply feel more at home in the weight room, upLIFT offers a supportive community and a dedicated space to grow. The program is structured for steady progression throughout the semester, but you’re welcome to drop in anytime and join at your own pace. 
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 No registration required 
 FREE for students with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 Where and when? 
 
 Beginning February 3, ending April 23 
 Tuesdays 3 PM - 4 PM, Wednesdays 6 PM - 7 PM, and Thursdays 2 PM - 3 PM

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: The DJ Academy: Music Matters 101
description:
DJing is one of the original elements of Hip Hop and is often considered the first. Hip Hop began in the Bronx during the 1970s at community block parties, where DJs used turntables to bring people together through music. Early pioneers like DJ Kool Herc introduced breakbeats by looping the most rhythmic parts of records, creating the foundation for breaking and shaping how dancers and MCs interacted with the music. 
 As Hip Hop evolved, DJing became the musical backbone of the culture. DJs provide the beats for MCing, set the tempo for dancers, and control the energy of Hip Hop spaces by reading the crowd and responding in real time. Through techniques like scratching, cutting, and beat juggling, DJs helped define Hip Hop’s sound while preserving its history and passing down cultural knowledge. 
 This class introduces the basics of DJing and how music shapes the dance experience. DJ Bascis will explain core concepts such as  tempo, rhythm, and song structure , helping students understand how music guides movement and energy on the dance floor. 
 Participants will learn how DJs choose music, create smooth transitions, and adjust the vibe based on the room.  
 Through simple examples and live demonstrations, students will build confidence in listening to music with intention. This can bewhether they are dancing, freestyling, or interested in DJing themselves. 
 This class is designed for  beginners and college students , with no prior DJ or music experience required.

title: NASO General Body Meeting
description: Join us for the Native African Student Organization's General Body Meeting! This is a space where we come together to celebrate and explore the richness of African cultures, while also connecting with other cultures from around the world. At each meeting, we'll engage in lively discussions, learn about Africa’s diverse history, traditions, and current events, and empower each other to understand and embrace our heritage. Whether you're looking to deepen your cultural knowledge, make meaningful connections, or simply have fun with fellow students who share a passion for Africa and global cultures, this is the place to be! Let’s build a supportive community, amplify African voices on campus, and create lasting friendships. All are welcome, come, learn, share, and connect!

title: Spanish Writing Center - Workshop Series - Online - April 2026
organization: Center for Latino Heritage & Spanish Language Excellence
description: This workshop offers practical guidance on how to write a personal opinion in a clear, organized, and persuasive manner. Through simple steps, participants will explore how to formulate a thesis, develop solid arguments, and support their ideas with examples. In addition, they will work on the use of transition words and expressions to connect ideas coherently and fluently. Upon completion, students will have concrete tools to express their opinions confidently and accurately in different academic contexts.

title: IDEALS, INTERESTS, AND INTERNATIONAL ENGAGEMENT: THE UNITED STATES IN WORLD AFFAIRS
location: Presentation Hall (College of Communication and Media)
description: America’s role in shaping the global political and economic order has shifted repeatedly over the last 250 years, reflecting the evolution of American interests and longstanding debates regarding the role of the United States in world affairs. Drawing on foundational principles, pivotal historical moments, and contemporary challenges, this lecture explores how American power, values, and institutions have influenced international norms, security, and governance and also how international dynamics have shaped American democracy. The lecture considers tensions between ideals and practices – democracy, markets, sovereignty, nation-building, imperialism, isolationism, intervention – in U.S. engagement abroad. Participants will be invited to reflect on the ways in which American leadership on the global stage has shaped our nation and what that implies in the current era.

title: Understanding Rights and Responsibilities— Immigration Policy
description:
As immigration policies develop, it is best to stay educated. Know your rights and responsibilities! 
 Join the New Jersey Consortium for Immigrant Children for a webinar on key legal and policy issues impacting the Montclair community. Information will be provided on immigration statuses, policy updates, legal protections, judicial vs. administrative orders, and understanding your rights if encountering law enforcement. Sessions are open for students, family, faculty, and staff in both English and Spanish.  
 The New Jersey Consortium for Immigrant Children (NJCIC) is a state-wide legal and policy advocacy and education organization specializing in youth immigration. They provide objective legal resources, aid, and advice on immigration rights. 
 Student & Family English Session: March 4, 2:30-3:45:  https://us06web.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_iGJLl9ZWR7KXRUE_aniMsA 
 Student & Family Spanish Session: April 9, 5:30-6:45: 
 https://us06web.zoom.us/j/82724283081?pwd=KzAjQw24vxqmzbURBXGmbBLV3V60m3.1

title: Cru Large Group!
description:
Cru is a caring community passionate about connecting people to Jesus Christ!  Join us in learning together on Who Christ is, building a personal relationship with Him, and joining a community filled with love and open arms!  
 This semester, we will be focusing on the theme  "Identity in Christ."  We pray that our students will learn more about who they are in Christ, and look at some examples of people in the Bible where God revealed their true identity in Christ! 
 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

title: Tri Sigma Initiation
description: Tri Sigma initiation is a meaningful ceremony that marks the transition from new member to fully initiated sister within the sorority. It is a formal and reflective experience centered on the organization’s values of wisdom, power, faith, hope, and love. During initiation, members learn more deeply about Tri Sigma’s traditions, history, and lifelong commitment to sisterhood, service, and personal growth. The ceremony symbolizes belonging, responsibility, and the shared bond that connects all Tri Sigma members across chapters and generations.

title: Tri Sigma Initiation
description: Tri Sigma initiation is a meaningful ceremony that marks the transition from new member to fully initiated sister within the sorority. title: Bearfort Mountain (Advanced)
description:
Join Outdoor Adventure for one of the most strenuous but spectacular hikes of the New Jersey and New York area. As we hike the Bearfort Mountain ridge past the Greenwood Lake, rhododendron tunnel, surprise lake, and west pond. Sure to be a breathtaking view the whole way up to the summit of the mountain.  
   
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 Register in the Student Recreation Center main office, on Fusion, or over the phone (973-655-3340). 
 Cost for Students  $10; Faculty/Staff $20 
 
   
 Where and when? 
 
 Saturday, April 11, 2026 
 10:00am –5:00pm 
 Begins at Student Recreation Center 
 
   
 What to bring:  Water, lunch, weather appropriate clothing, boots ( sneakers not acceptable ), lunch, snacks, and sunscreen. 
   
 Potential Hazards:  Unpredictable weather changes, sunburn/heat exhaustion, dehydration, allergic reactions/poisonous plants, insect bites and injury by running, including sprains, lacerations, abrasions and fractures.

title: Show Them Shege
description: Join NASO for our Interhouse Sports & Cookout Event! Get active with fun games and friendly competition, and show off your moves on the dance floor. We’ll have great music, good vibes, and plenty of delicious food fresh off the grill. Don’t miss this chance to connect, compete, and celebrate with the community. It’s all about fun, culture, and unity.

title: New York Mets vs Oakland Athletics
description:
Catch the action live as the New York Mets take on the Oakland Athletics on April 11th at 4:10 PM at Citi Field! Join fellow students for an exciting afternoon of baseball, school spirit, and big-league fun. No need to worry about transportation — bus service will be provided from the Montclair Rec Center, making it easy to be part of the action. Don’ t miss this chance to experience the energy of a live MLB game with your friends! 
   
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 Registration is Open from  3/16/2026 - 4/10/2026 
 Tickets are $35 
 
 When and where? 
 
 Saturday, April 11, 2026 
 2pm pick up time at the Student Recreation Center 
 City Field, Queens , NYC

title: MILF Round 4

title: Spring Retreat
description:
Join Campus Activities for our Spring Student Retreat  a chance to step away from campus, connect with other students, and enjoy a day filled with activities, good food, and a refreshing change of scenery. This trip is designed to help you relax, recharge, and make new memories while participating in group experiences and social opportunities throughout the day. 
 The trip is open to current Bloomfield/Montclair State students only. Spots are limited and available on a first-come, first-served basis. 
 A  $5 reservation fee  is required to secure your spot at the time of sign-up. 
 Transportation will be provided, and the bus will depart from and return to the Bloomfield Campus. All meals are included, and some snacks will be provided. Students are encouraged to wear comfortable clothing and shoes suitable for a full day of activities. 
 Additional trip details, including itinerary information and preparation instructions, will be shared with students once their registration and reservation are confirmed.

title: Croton Aqueduct Bike Trip
description:
Get ready for a scenic spin through history as we ride the legendary Old Croton Aqueduct! This unforgettable bike trip takes you along one of New York’s most beautiful and peaceful trails, where tree-lined paths, and charming river views, create the perfect backdrop for a day outdoors. As we cruise along the trail you’ll enjoy plenty of photo-worthy stops along the way. Expect a relaxed pace with time to explore, snack, and soak in the scenery. Whether you're in it for the fresh air, the history, or just a joyful ride with great company, this Croton Aqueduct adventure is a perfect blend of nature, culture, and fun on two wheels!  
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 Register online through  Fusion , in the Student Recreation Center's main office, or over the phone (973-655-3340). 
 Cost for Students - $10 | Faculty/Staff - $20 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Sunday, April 12, 2026 
 10:00 am - 5:00 pm 
 Croton Aqueduct, NJ - Begins and ends at Student Recreation Center 
 
 What to bring: 
 
 Money for spending, lunch, water, comfortable shoes, sunscreen. 
 
 Potential Hazards:  Hazardous weather, poisonous plants/allergies, insect bites, unpredictable weather changes, sunburn/heat exhaustion, dehydration, and injuries, including sprains/strains, abrasions, lacerations and fractures.

title: Free Swim Lessons *Intermediate*
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Brief Description:  
 Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM

description: Join the Office of International Academic Initiatives to learn about the Study Abroad Opportunities that Montclair State University has to offer.  All Montclair / Bloomfield Campus Students are Invited to Attend!

title: Pickle Palooza!
description: Join us for Pickle Palooza! A celebration of the sandwich's polarizing pal, the  pickle!  There will be pickle tastings, photo opps, costumes, information on voting, gardening, mason jar decorating, and so much more. Check it out! A silly celebration to celebrate spring! It'll be a big dill!

title: Montclair Unraveled General Body Meeting!
description:
Do you want to learn a new knitting or crochet pattern? Do you want to make a cool craft but can't pick one or figure out where to start? Then come to Montclair Unraveled!  
 Join us and learn how to make something new like accessories, decor, or plushies! Already have something you're working on? Feel free to make some progress here! All are welcome, whether you have the most craft experience possible or none at all. Come by and enjoy the company of others who share your passions for the fiber arts!

description: Come hang out with the SLAM E-Board and get involved in shaping our events for the semester! Our General Body Meetings are a space for students to learn about upcoming programs, share ideas, and help plan and execute events that bring the campus together. Whether you’re interested in event planning, marketing, logistics, or just want your voice heard, this is the place to be. We’ll be discussing what’s ahead for the semester, ways to get involved, and how you can make a real impact through SLAM. No experience is needed—just bring your ideas, energy, and excitement to collaborate with us!

title: upLIFT
description:
Step into the brand-new PLAE Room and discover upLIFT—a judgement-free program designed to help every student, from complete beginners to seasoned gym-goers, feel confident and capable with free-weight training. Learn proper lifting technique, get personalized form checks, and master the basics of creating your own effective workout programs. Whether you’re looking to meet other students who love to lift, pursue new fitness goals, or simply feel more at home in the weight room, upLIFT offers a supportive community and a dedicated space to grow. The program is structured for steady progression throughout the semester, but you’re welcome to drop in anytime and join at your own pace. 
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 No registration required 
 FREE for students with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 Where and when? 
 
 Beginning February 3, ending April 23 
 Tuesdays 3 PM - 4 PM, Wednesdays 6 PM - 7 PM, and Thursdays 2 PM - 3 PM 
 Student Recreation Center PLAE Room

title: 2026 Class Gift Tabling - Information and Philanthropy Cord Pick-Up
description:
Each year, our graduating class participates in a proud Class Gift tradition where members of the class invest in the University by supporting areas of Montclair State University that are most important to them. We invite the Class of 2026 to come together to show your support! 
 All gifts to Montclair count! Make your gift to any area of campus you feel most passionate about – such as the Emergency Book Fund, The Red Hawk Pantry, your school or college, The Fund for Montclair State or athletic program. 
 Your gift will pay it forward for future Red Hawks and kick-start your philanthropic connection to Montclair. 
 
 Commemorate your class year! Make a gift of at least  $20.26  and you’ll receive your customized philanthropy cord to wear over your commencement robe.  
 For a gift of  $40 , celebrate this milestone with your family, friends and colleagues by having your message displayed on the screen at the Commencement you will be participating in, and receive a customized philanthropy cord. 
 
 How do I get my customized philanthropy cord? 
 Customized philanthropy cords will be available for pick-up: 
 
 Tuesday, October 28 from 1:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Thursday, November 20  from 1:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Tuesday, December 2 from 12:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Bloomfield Campus Graduation Fair: Wednesday, December 10th from 12:00 – 6:00 p.m. in Deacon’s Den, Talbott Hall  (for Bloomfield graduates only) 
 Montclair Campus Graduation Fairs: Thursday, December 11th from 10:00 a.m. – 7:00 p.m. in the Student Center Ballrooms  (for Montclair or Bloomfield graduates) 
 
 Graduates can also arrange to pick up their philanthropy cords in the Overlook Corporate Center, 150 Clove Road, Little Falls, NJ during business hours, Monday through Friday, 8:30 a.m. – 4:30 p.m. Philanthropy cords can also be mailed to those who cannot pick it up. The last day we will mail the cords is Monday, December 22, 2025 at 2:30 p.m. Please contact James Stewart, Associate Director of Annual Giving at stewartj@montclair.edu or 973-655-5328 to finalize options to get your cords for the Winter Commencement. 
 Every student has benefitted from donor generosity to areas of academic support, emergency funding for students and overall priorities to boost students’ success every day. Thank you for paying it forward! For more information, please contact James Stewart, Associate Director of Annual Giving, at 973-655-5328 or stewartj@montclair.edu.

title: The DJ Academy: Music Matters 101
description:
DJing is one of the original elements of Hip Hop and is often considered the first. Hip Hop began in the Bronx during the 1970s at community block parties, where DJs used turntables to bring people together through music. Early pioneers like DJ Kool Herc introduced breakbeats by looping the most rhythmic parts of records, creating the foundation for breaking and shaping how dancers and MCs interacted with the music. 
 As Hip Hop evolved, DJing became the musical backbone of the culture. DJs provide the beats for MCing, set the tempo for dancers, and control the energy of Hip Hop spaces by reading the crowd and responding in real time. Through techniques like scratching, cutting, and beat juggling, DJs helped define Hip Hop’s sound while preserving its history and passing down cultural knowledge. 
 This class introduces the basics of DJing and how music shapes the dance experience. DJ Bascis will explain core concepts such as  tempo, rhythm, and song structure , helping students understand how music guides movement and energy on the dance floor. 
 Participants will learn how DJs choose music, create smooth transitions, and adjust the vibe based on the room.  
 Through simple examples and live demonstrations, students will build confidence in listening to music with intention. This can bewhether they are dancing, freestyling, or interested in DJing themselves. 
 This class is designed for  beginners and college students , with no prior DJ or music experience required.

At each meeting, we'll engage in lively discussions, learn about Africa’s diverse history, traditions, and current events, and empower each other to understand and embrace our heritage. Whether you're looking to deepen your cultural knowledge, make meaningful connections, or simply have fun with fellow students who share a passion for Africa and global cultures, this is the place to be! Let’s build a supportive community, amplify African voices on campus, and create lasting friendships. All are welcome, come, learn, share, and connect!

description:

 This semester, we will be focusing on the theme  "Identity in Christ."  We pray that our students will learn more about who they are in Christ, and look at some examples of people in the Bible where God revealed their true identity in Christ! 
 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

Flower picking costs $1for each flower picked!

 Saturday, April 18, 2026 
 10:00 am - 5:00 pm 
 Cream Ridge, NJ - Begins and ends at Student Recreation Center

 Money for spending, lunch, water, comfortable shoes, sunscreen.

title: Safe Space Training
description:
Our Safe Space Training is an intensive, interactive training that provides attendees with information and tools to combat homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, cissexism and heterosexism, on campus and beyond. Through interactive activities and discussion, participants will personally reflect on their own experiences to enhance their personal and professional development, provide further education, and finally, identify ways to create change on campus and beyond. 
 All sessions are three hours and are first-come, first-served. Pre-registration is required. Registrants are expected to attend the full session. Only individuals who have fully completed the Safe Space Program and have agreed to the expectations of its membership are able to display the sticker/button of our program. Refreshments are not provided; however, you are more than welcome to bring your lunch, coffee, snacks, etc.

title: Study Abroad 101

Whether you want to stay as close to home as Pennsylvania or travel as far away as South Korea, Montclair State University has programs for you.

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: MSU Political Science Club General Body Meeting
description: Join us for our General Body Meetings every Wednesday from 2:00 to 3:15 p.m. in Dickson Hall, Room 272! Don't miss this opportunity to deepen your understanding of political issues and connect with fellow students!

title: The DJ Academy: Music Matters 101
description:
DJing is one of the original elements of Hip Hop and is often considered the first. Hip Hop began in the Bronx during the 1970s at community block parties, where DJs used turntables to bring people together through music. Early pioneers like DJ Kool Herc introduced breakbeats by looping the most rhythmic parts of records, creating the foundation for breaking and shaping how dancers and MCs interacted with the music. 
 As Hip Hop evolved, DJing became the musical backbone of the culture. DJs provide the beats for MCing, set the tempo for dancers, and control the energy of Hip Hop spaces by reading the crowd and responding in real time. Through techniques like scratching, cutting, and beat juggling, DJs helped define Hip Hop’s sound while preserving its history and passing down cultural knowledge. 
 This class introduces the basics of DJing and how music shapes the dance experience. DJ Bascis will explain core concepts such as  tempo, rhythm, and song structure , helping students understand how music guides movement and energy on the dance floor. 
 Participants will learn how DJs choose music, create smooth transitions, and adjust the vibe based on the room.  
 Through simple examples and live demonstrations, students will build confidence in listening to music with intention. This can bewhether they are dancing, freestyling, or interested in DJing themselves. 
 This class is designed for  beginners and college students , with no prior DJ or music experience required.

title: NASO General Body Meeting
description: Join us for the Native African Student Organization's General Body Meeting! This is a space where we come together to celebrate and explore the richness of African cultures, while also connecting with other cultures from around the world. At each meeting, we'll engage in lively discussions, learn about Africa’s diverse history, traditions, and current events, and empower each other to understand and embrace our heritage. Whether you're looking to deepen your cultural knowledge, make meaningful connections, or simply have fun with fellow students who share a passion for Africa and global cultures, this is the place to be! Let’s build a supportive community, amplify African voices on campus, and create lasting friendships. All are welcome, come, learn, share, and connect!

title: WMSC General Meeting
location: College of Communication and Media Room 1020
description:
WMSC's weekly member meeting to go over the newest and most important information regarding the station, and what each team is up to. 
   
 On-air DJs are required to attend several of these meetings throughout the semester.

title: AI Literacy for Educators
description: The AI literacy for educators designed to support educators in building a strong, practical understanding of artificial intelligence in educational contexts. This workshop will help educators understand foundational AI concepts, critically evaluate AI tools and outputs, recognize how bias and inequity can emerge in AI systems, and examine the ethical and societal implications of AI use in teaching and learning. Participants will also explore strategies for working with AI responsibly, emphasizing informed decision-making and human-centered AI practice. RSVP: https://www.tickettailor.com/events/adpcenterforlearningtechnologies

title: MASA General Miembro Meeting
description: Join the Mexican-American Student Association for our weekly General Miembro Meeting where we have fun activities planned to learn about Mexican culture! Check out our instagram @montclair_masa for this week's topic!

title: General Body Meeting
description: Join us for weekly discussions, presentations, ice breakers, and more!

title: AI & Ethics: Navigating Responsibility in the Age of Algorithms
description: This workshop introduces core principles of AI ethics and their implications for education, policy, and everyday use. Participants will examine case studies, identify risks, and develop strategies for responsible, equitable, and transparent AI integration. RSVP: https://www.tickettailor.com/events/adpcenterforlearningtechnologies

title: upLIFT
description:
Step into the brand-new PLAE Room and discover upLIFT—a judgement-free program designed to help every student, from complete beginners to seasoned gym-goers, feel confident and capable with free-weight training. Learn proper lifting technique, get personalized form checks, and master the basics of creating your own effective workout programs. Whether you’re looking to meet other students who love to lift, pursue new fitness goals, or simply feel more at home in the weight room, upLIFT offers a supportive community and a dedicated space to grow. The program is structured for steady progression throughout the semester, but you’re welcome to drop in anytime and join at your own pace. 
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 No registration required 
 FREE for students with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 Where and when? 
 
 Beginning February 3, ending April 23 
 Tuesdays 3 PM - 4 PM, Wednesdays 6 PM - 7 PM, and Thursdays 2 PM - 3 PM 
 Student Recreation Center PLAE Room

title: Black Girl Recess
organization: Bloomfield Swing Phi Swing Social Fellowship, Inc.
description:
Black Girl Recess is a welcoming and affirming space designed to encourage rest, reflection, and connection for women on campus. While the event centers the experiences of Black women,  any young woman on campus who feels this space would be meaningful to her is encouraged to attend . 
 This event provides an opportunity for participants to step away from daily responsibilities and engage in open conversation around self-care, balance, and personal well-being. Attendees will reflect on the many roles they navigate in their academic and personal lives and explore healthy ways to manage stress, prioritize themselves, and support one another. 
   
 The event will include interactive stations, open conversation, and opportunities for reflection in a relaxed and affirming environment. Black Girl Recess promotes self-care, balance, and empowerment while fostering meaningful connection and support among participants.

description:
NAACP is back for Spring 2026—and we’re leveling up.  Every  Thursday from 3:30–4:45 PM , tap in for weekly discussions that spark conversation, inspire change, and build community. 
 From  civil rights and mental health to campus advocacy and organizing , each week features a new topic rooted in the NAACP’s mission. Whether you want to speak up, listen, or just vibe with like-minded students, this is your space. Come as you are—everyone belongs here. 🖤

title: Cru Large Group!
description:
Cru is a caring community passionate about connecting people to Jesus Christ!  Join us in learning together on Who Christ is, building a personal relationship with Him, and joining a community filled with love and open arms!  
 This semester, we will be focusing on the theme  "Identity in Christ."  We pray that our students will learn more about who they are in Christ, and look at some examples of people in the Bible where God revealed their true identity in Christ! 
 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

title: Black River (Easy)
description:
Join us for a gorgeous hike through Hacklebarney state park. The trail features the Black River as a centerpiece and is quite stunning in the spring season. 
   
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 Register in the Student Recreation Center main office or over the phone (973-655-3340). 
 Cost for Students $10 | Faculty/Staff/Community $20 
 
   
 Where and when? 
 
 Sunday, April 26th, 2026 
 10am-4pm  
 Bus leaves from Student Recreation Center 
 
   
 What to bring:  Water, Lunch, and Boots or Sneakers 
   
 Potential Hazards:  Unpredictable weather changes, sunburn/heat exhaustion, limited vision, dehydration, allergic reactions/poisonous plants, insect bites, and injury by running, including sprains, lacerations, abrasions and fractures.

title: Denim Day 2026: Mind the Gaps, Move Forward
description:
April is Sexual Assault Awareness Month, and together, we can break the silence.  The Montclair State University Police Department and the Office of Advocacy & Outreach are committed to fostering a campus where survivors feel heard, supported, and empowered.  It starts with believing. It starts with you.  By offering a safe and affirming response to those who disclose gender-based and sexual violence, we can create lasting change. Let’s stand together to end the cycle of silence—because  every voice matters, and every action counts. 
 Denim Day is recognized internationally as a day of action and awareness, encouraging people to wear denim to challenge victim-blaming and educate others about sexual violence.  This year, Denim Day falls on Wednesday, April 29, 2026. 
 The University Police and  Office of Advocacy & Outreach and the Office of Advocacy and Community Resilience , in partnership with over 30 campus and local community organizations, invites you to join us  from 9 a.m. to 12 p.m. at the Amphitheater  for a powerful awareness event honoring survivors and increasing awareness of available resources. 
 Despite the  gaps  that still exist in the criminal justice system, in resources, and in prevention education,  we will move forward together  as a community. As part of this commitment, we will walk  one mile around campus in solidarity with survivors.

title: Prestigious Scholarships Info Session
description: Are you a junior or senior interested in graduate school, research, public service, or international experiences? The Prestigious Scholarships Program is here to support you!  A prestigious scholarship provides you with the opportunity to develop your skills and reach your goals through engagement with people and places around the world. Montclair’s Prestigious Scholarships Program helps all students and alumni learn of and apply for nationally and internationally competitive and prestigious awards. These awards fund a wide range of opportunities, as well as independent research projects, and many are connected to undergraduate and graduate degree programs or internships around the globe.

title: MSU Political Science Club General Body Meeting
description: Join us for our General Body Meetings every Wednesday from 2:00 to 3:15 p.m. in Dickson Hall, Room 272! Engage in vibrant discussions about domestic and international politics, where all students are welcome to share their thoughts. Each meeting includes a research presentation followed by open discussion, encouraging diverse perspectives and debates. Don't miss this opportunity to deepen your understanding of political issues and connect with fellow students!

title: Red Hawk Pantry
description:
Visiting the Pantry: 
 1) Please have your Event Pass, CWID and have a  PantrySoft Registration .  2) Please bring your own shopping bag and ID card! ***Visitors are allowed to come once/week*** 
 Our Mission:   We aim to address food insecurity across Montclair State University. The Red Hawk Pantry is open to all students, staff, and faculty at no cost. If you are unable to visit during our regular hours, please reach out via email at redhawkpantry@montclair.edu Stay updated by following us on Instagram: @montclair_redhawkpantry 
   
 🍎 Fall 2025 Hours 
 
 Mondays: 1:30-3:30pm 
 Wednesdays: 5-7pm 
 Saturdays: 11-1pm

title: Canva Masterclass: Advanced Pro Tools & Design Hacks
description: Ready to level up your Canva skills? This advanced workshop dives into powerful features like animations, brand kits, collaboration tools, and interactive content creation. Go beyond the basics and learn how to streamline your design process with features like Canva’s Whiteboard for brainstorming, Website Builder for creating interactive web pages, and Presentation Mode with embedded video and transitions. Whether you're building classroom resources, school branding materials, or engaging digital content. Participants will also explore team templates, content scheduling, and how to manage brand consistency across multiple projects. RSVP: https://www.tickettailor.com/events/adpcenterforlearningtechnologies

title: Fireside Chats
description:
Hang out and have casual conversations with other students while enjoying refreshments! Join us on Thursdays from 3:15-4:15pm.  
 What are Fireside Chats: 
 
 A space for students to meet, connect, and have a casual conversation about a given topic, or anything else that feels comfortable for everyone else. It can be about the school climate, student life in general, or your favorite show. All students are welcome!

title: Walk Into Your Finals With Tacos
description:
Fuel up before finals with a tasty boost! Stop by to grab a walking taco—easy to carry, fun to customize, and perfect for powering you through studying. Swing in, snack up, and step into finals week feeling ready to go! 
   
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 No registration required 
 FREE for students with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 Where and when? 
 
 Thursday, April 30 
 5pm-7pm, must be checked in by 8:30pm to participate 
 Student Recreation Center Lounge

title: Visit the University Galleries' Spring 2026 Exhibition! Carpe Diem: Select Alumni in the Visual Arts
location: George Segal Gallery, 4th Floor of the Red Hawk Deck
description:
On view from February 3 – May 3, 2026 in the George Segal Gallery. Public hours are Tuesday – Friday, 12 to 4 pm. 
   
 Admission is free, open to the public.  Learn more about this exhibition 
   
 Carpe Diem: Select Alumni in the Visual Arts  is a group exhibition presented by the Office for Development and Alumni Engagement and hosted by the University Galleries.  Carpe Diem  brings together twelve accomplished alumni working in a range of media. 
   
 Curated by Sally Morgan Lehman, who has taught in the Department of Art and Design at Montclair and is owner and director of Morgan Lehman Gallery in New York City,  Carpe Diem  highlights the breadth of artistic practices fostered at Montclair and the lasting impact of its visual arts alumni. 
   
 Featured artists include Flávia Berindoague ’13, Bisa Butler ’05, Jonathan Calm ’97, Kyle Coniglio ’10, Alyssa Fanning ’12, Allen Ginsberg (1943), Márta Kucsora (2005–06), Michael Manning ’11, Nancy Bergman Pantirer ’80, Tiffany Perez ’09, William Pope.L ’78, and Maria Valdivia ’24.

title: Mindfulness Meditation
description:
Online. Mindfulness Meditation is the practice of being self-aware with an extra focus on your breath. Open to all who are interested in learning about meditation and developing mindfulness in daily life. Participate with video or audio only. 
 **Please note that we cannot verify attendance at this event

title: CPT Workshop - International Students (F-1 Visa Holders) Only
description: Learn more about Curricular Practical Training (CPT) for F-1 students. Any student planning to apply for CPT is REQUIRED to attend a workshop before they can apply. This workshop is for CURRENT students ONLY - any other attendees will be removed.

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: OPT Workshop - International Students (F-1 Visa Holders) Only
description: Learn more about pre-completion and post-completion Optional Practical Training (OPT) for F-1 students. Any student planning to apply for OPT is REQUIRED to attend a workshop before they can apply. This workshop is for CURRENT students ONLY - any other attendees will be removed.

title: Safe Space Training
description:
Our Safe Space Training is an intensive, interactive training that provides attendees with information and tools to combat homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, cissexism and heterosexism, on campus and beyond. Through interactive activities and discussion, participants will personally reflect on their own experiences to enhance their personal and professional development, provide further education, and finally, identify ways to create change on campus and beyond. 
 All sessions are three hours and are first-come, first-served. Pre-registration is required. Registrants are expected to attend the full session. Only individuals who have fully completed the Safe Space Program and have agreed to the expectations of its membership are able to display the sticker/button of our program. Refreshments are not provided; however, you are more than welcome to bring your lunch, coffee, snacks, etc.
